title: 108_s553
content: The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to offer accounts with up to 24 transfers per month for any purpose, without being subject to certain restrictions. The "Payment of Interest on Reserves at Federal Reserve Banks" is addressed in Section 3. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with payments made quarterly at rates not exceeding short-term interest rates. The Board may issue regulations on earnings payments and distribution to these institutions. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with payments made quarterly at rates not exceeding short-term interest rates. Regulations are issued regarding the payment and distribution of earnings to these institutions. Responsibilities are outlined for depository institutions, Federal home loan banks, and the National Credit Union Administration Central Liquidity Facility regarding the crediting and distribution of earnings from balances maintained at a Federal reserve bank. The Federal Reserve Act allows depository institutions to earn interest on balances held at a Federal Reserve bank. Depository institutions are defined to include trust companies, certain corporations, and branches of foreign banks. Authorization is given for pass-through reserves for member banks. The Federal Reserve Act allows depository institutions to earn interest on balances held at a Federal Reserve bank. Authorization is given for pass-through reserves for member banks, with amendments made to certain sections of the Act. SEC. 4 amends the Federal Reserve Act to allow for a reserve ratio not greater than 3 percent (which may be zero) and a ratio not less than 8 percent (which may be zero). SEC. 5 addresses the transfer of Federal Reserve surpluses. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow additional transfers from surplus funds to cover interest payments for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow transfers from surplus funds to cover the net cost of section 19(b)(12) for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The Federal Reserve Board will determine the amount each bank pays, and no bank can replenish its surplus fund with transferred amounts. Additionally, a technical and conforming amendment is made to Section 7(a) of the Act. During fiscal years 2003 through 2007, any excess amount in the surplus fund of a Federal Reserve bank, exceeding 3 percent of the paid-in capital and surplus of member banks, will be transferred to the Treasury's general fund.
